segments.text: Well, speaking of the books, Reisner's books, have you ever read any of the books that any of the other POWs have written?
Oh, yeah, I have.
I've read Robbie's book, and I read my old roommate, Red McDaniel, wrote a book.
I don't remember all of them at the moment, but I did read most of them.
Uh-huh.
Okay.
There were some prisoners released early, and the people like we talk about, the cooperated.
They were released early, obviously, because they did cooperate.
What was the POW's feelings in the camp about those men?
Well, we felt they were dead wrong to accept preferential treatment and so on.
But the big thing that was so wrong about it was that it played right into the hands of the Vietnam propagandists.
They served their purpose by releasing three people at a time and saying,

You know, they had those people giving the answers that they were assured, you know, before they released them, that they had people that are going to say the things they wanted them to say when they got out.
And that's why they released them.
And they did it strictly for the benefit of the Vietnamese, not for anything other than that.
I mean, North Vietnam.
That was cooperating to the nth degree with the enemy.
And of course, we all had discussed that and said that we would not get involved in a program that would lead to something like that.
Because you could very easily detect what was going on if
If they started moving in that kind of a direction with you, you'd know what they were up to.
Actually, the only one person that our so-called senior officers authorized to go along with the D and try to get released was a guy named
I never think of these names for so many years.
He was a young seaman who they captured in a real freak way up there, and he was with us for a while.
He had fallen overboard off of a destroyer out in the Gulf of Tonkin and got picked up by Vietnamese fishermen.
And he was in our prison system.
He was an American.
And his name was something like Hagler or Hagar.
I've forgotten his name now.
But anyhow, he was a young fella.
Wasn't an officer.
And I think our people, our senior guys had told him when he reported that they were making approaches to him along the lines that led him to think that they might be thinking about sending him.
And they told him to go ahead and play along with them.
and obtain his release, and they gave him information to take home with him.
So he was the only one of the, I think there were 12 overall that got released.
None of them were authorized to do that except him.
Most people...
the POWs as having to endure the hardships and everything, but your family, of course, was worried.
Did they ever have any notice that you were a prisoner of war, or were you just considered missing for that time?
I was missing until June of 1970 is when Ann found out.
So you'd been over there about two years then, right?
Well, I was shot down in December of 67, so 68, 69.
It was two and a half years or so.
when she finally got some confirmation that I was alive.
That's the first she'd heard of me in any way.
But that came as a real surprise to me, and I didn't know it until I got home because my assumption from the beginning was that I was known to be a prisoner because I had made several transmissions
on my little radio coming down in the parachute.
You know, this parachute opens at 13,000 feet, and I was coming down for a long time, and I was up pretty high when I made the transmissions.
We had good communications coverage of the whole area up there in Package 6 with communications aircraft, special aircraft that had all the communications gear on.
So, you know, I just didn't dream that those communications, that those transmissions that I made weren't recorded.
I just assumed they were.
And went from there, I just didn't, from the very beginning, I just said, well, you know, they know I'm okay.
But
That wasn't the case at all.
They didn't get anything.
And nobody, and I had a lot of close friends in the war zone down there, and in the headquarters down at Seventh Air Force, and so on.
General Bo, among them, General Tomlin, and they all tried to get, they screened every communication they could find and so on, tried to get some clue, but nobody knew anything.
I mean, there wasn't any communications that they could make any determination, positive determination that I had made.
So I was strictly missing an ax until one time.
You did arrive back in the States.
What was your response to the Americans' actions at the time?
I mean, POWs were given a fairly warm welcome, and then again, there were the awarding senators also, the people that were opposing the war.
I didn't see any of those.
All I ever got when we got back was strictly, you know, fantastic reception from everybody that I came in contact with.
And it was just...
a very euphoric time for a good while.
Well, it hasn't stopped yet.
How was it like to see your kids again?
They'd grown up while you were gone, or at least six years change or seven years change?
Yeah, right.
They'd grown quite a bit.
My kids ranged in age from seven to 14.
And then when I got home, they ranged from 13 to 20.
That was quite a change.
Kathy was beginning her junior year, I suppose, in college.
And John was...
It was sophomore year.
So there was a big chance they'd grown up, of course.
But they really hadn't changed personality-wise.
The kids were all the same.
And I had gotten a few little snapshots in the last year or so while I was up there.
And also, when I arrived at Clark,
I had a big letter with some current pictures and that sort of thing were there for me.
I didn't have any trouble recognizing my family.
Well, to close it up, do you have any statements to summarize your feelings about the conflict in Vietnam or about the hardships you had to endure, the men over there had to endure?
No, I don't know specifically.
The Vietnam War turned out most unfortunately.
I think, though, that in the fall of 72, when it became pretty obvious to us up there, too, because a lot of things were happening, that our release was getting pretty close.
And that was before the election, if you recall, in November.
They publicized this famous statement by Kissinger that peace is at hand or something like that.
So it was getting close.
And then the obvious thing happened that always happens with the Vietnamese.
There's no way you can negotiate with them anything reasonable.
So at the last minute, they just threw a monkey wrench into the whole thing.
And so the president sent the B-52s to Hanoi in December.
For 11 days, they had airplanes in the sky 24 hours a day over Hanoi.
B-52s at night mostly, and during the day, fighters and so on.

That 11 days typifies, well, in the first place, it was a very courageous decision that had to be made by the one man alone, and he had to do it, and he did it knowing that, you know, there would be a lot of criticism about it and so on.
But it had to be done, and it was very effective.
If he hadn't have done that, chances are, you know, we might still be in Vietnam.
But those 11 days wiped them out.
And it didn't, you know, they very selectively bombed the different areas, the industrial areas and so on up there.
All around Hanoi, I was right underneath it all, you know, in the prison.
Plaster was coming off the walls in there.
So, you know, I could see what was happening.
But if we had done that, you know, like in 1964, the war would have been over in a week.
We wouldn't have lost 50,000 people in over a period of, you know, eight, nine years.
So, that's hindsight, but it
You know, it's something that a lot of people knew about and knew should have been done.
But that war, of course, as everybody knows, got involved in the political process and the trying to run the war from Washington and without
without any regard for military principles and so on, is what got us in trouble with Vietnam.
Had we gone into that war with the intention of winning it right away, it would have been over within a matter of weeks.
There wouldn't have been any problem whatsoever.
You know, again, that's hindsight.
If Barry Goldwater had been elected in 1964, then we wouldn't have had a Vietnam War that would have lasted any time to amount to anything.
It would have been over in a real big hurry.
But that wasn't what made it happen.
But I, you know, as far as myself personally is concerned, I was just...
doing my job and I was one of those guys that never, you know, I didn't, I went up there and flew up over Hanoi every day and I did, expected to fly my full tour and not get shot down.
I just knew, you know, it wouldn't ever happen to me, but it sure as heck did.
I was one of the unfortunate few as far as that's concerned.
And when it happened, if it had cost me my life, it would have been, you know, that's the way it would have gone because I was just doing what I'm supposed to do.
And so I don't have any qualms about...
doing my job, being in the military, and taking what comes with that.
And for me, it turned out being in prison for a good long stretch, but that's the breaks as far as I'm concerned.
And I'm just extremely fortunate that in the end, it turned out the way it did.
And I got back to my family and a great life
the only country in the world to live in, you know, as far as I'm concerned.
So overall, I'm extremely fortunate and basically I'm fortunate to be an American.
And then, you know, to have all the things that that allows me to have, including my family and so on.
